abstracts.cdata!:
The audit largely concurs with the
            Implementation Completion Report ratings of the Romania
            Railway Rehabilitation Project, i.e., on a highly
            satisfactory project outcome, highly likely sustainability,
            and high institutional development impacts; and, while it
            also concurs with the highly satisfactory Borrower
            performance, the audit upgrades the Bank performance from
            satisfactory to highly satisfactory. Some insights, rather
            than lessons are offered from the success experience of this
            operation. It is first emphasized that policy changes are
            more likely to be implemented successfully when Bank support
            is provided right at the time when public entities have
            committed to the process of commercialization, and,
            supportive sector-wide reforms are being put in place.
            However, whenever railway companies are moving toward
            commercial operations, their long-term financial health
            needs to be assured by rationalizing subsidy support, and
            introducing an appropriate costing model. In addition, a
            critical success factor in a complex task, such as the
            installation of an integrated management system, is that
            sufficient technical supervision and support must be
            available to assist with problem solving as may arise.
            Further lessons point at maximizing the benefits of a
            complex information system, which require that middle and
            upper level management foresee, and understand the benefits
            of using the system; and, at the Public Service Obligation
            Subsidy, which should be for specific services that the
            Government considers socially necessary; such services
            should be transparent, explicitly defined, and fully
            compensated as part of a Contract Plan.

            DEVELOPMENT PROJ.,TF029112-PHRD-RAILWAY REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF030313-CANADIAN CTF FOR CENTRAL AND
            EASTERN EUROPE FY03 - ECA GENERAL,TF030428-CANADIAN CTF FOR CENTRAL AND

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is highly
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, and
            institutional development impacts are high, with a highly
            satisfactory borrower performance, and satisfactory Bank
            performance. Regardless of the highly satisfactory outcomes,
            lessons of experience suggest the following. The partnership
            in the loan - in this case between the Government, the
            Railways, and the Bank - bestows upon the Bank a greater
            responsibility than simply monitoring progress of the
            lending program, and progress on each of its components.
            Through the interaction with the Ministry of Transport and
            the Executive Management of the Railway, the Bank staff
            needs to understand the changing (Railway) environment, and
            share in the development of strategies to ensure the overall
            success of the Railway reform. In projects with significant
            institutional development, or restructuring objectives,
            supervision missions should review, and conduct consultation
            meetings beyond the project components framework, to guide
            the process towards the shared objectives between the client
            and the Bank, with encouragement by the Bank, and management
            assistance (Railway in this case) towards decisions that
            continue the reform programs, an in turn, building support
            for such actions at the Government level. The project's
            partnership, upon restructuring, needs to address details of
            a project's components only when needed, but when
            necessary, do so exceptionally. This was recognized by the
            Bank early in the review and supervision process, in
            connection with the Integrated Railway Information System,
            and increased consultations and reviews on this component,
            and its supporting telecommunications component, in order to
            provide the required expertise, and achieve success. General
            lessons further suggest that while lender/donor coordination
            is best managed by the borrower, discussions should take
            place with the Bank on the content of project interventions,
            prior to these being undertaken, and, given restructuring
            needs, appropriate importance should be given to the Mission
            Statement and Mandate, being Supervision the adequate phase
            for the details of the project's policy and
            institutional components, not during preparation which may
            be out of context.
